item.title: 【KitOps 1.0 release—proven in production and looking to CNCF】Kitops 1.0发行 - 生产并寻求CNCF
item.description:
【

Member post by Gorkem Ercan, CTO, Jozu

The merry band of maintainers and contributors at the KitOps project is happy to announce the 1.0 release of KitOps. Jozu kicked off the KitOps project after observing the significant challenges due to the fragmentation of AI/ML packaging and versioning. KitOps, which has been submitted to the CNCF Sandbox, is an open-source packaging and versioning solution designed for speed, security, and consistency in a variety of computing environments. The tool outfits AI/ML practitioners with a standardized OCI artifact called ModelKit, leveraging the widely embraced OCI standard. This enables organizations to manage, secure, and audit AI/ML projects effectively.

KitOps has one grand ambition: to bolster collaboration among data scientists, application developers, and SREs. Therefore we have created tools around ModelKit to serve all these groups. KitOps releases a CLI named kit which is used on desktops, in pipelines, and by tool integrations. We also release a GitHub Action and a Dagger module for use in AI/ML workflows. For data scientists, the PyKitOps library and the new MLFLow plugin provides a streamlined mechanism to share their work as ModelKits on any OCI registry of their choosing.

Since launching, KitOps has been installed over 45,000 times, and is being used in production by private enterprises with global footprints and security-conscious public sector development teams.

New in 1.0: Hugging Face Import or Generated ModelKits

One common use case of KitOps is assembling a secure and curated set of base models for internal consumption from third-party sources like Hugging Face. To make this even more easy, the kit CLI now includes a shiny new import command. Point it at a Hugging Face repository, and—presto! it generates a ModelKit ready to be served from your enterprise OCI registry.

But your favorite model is not always hosted on Hugging Face. The new kit init command automatically scans a directory and generates a Kitfile recipe. The Kitfile instructs the CLI exactly how to package everything into a ModelKit so you can securely share your AI/ML project with the rest of your crew in minutes.

This 1.0 release is more than features and a version bump—it’s a statement. The core features KitOps pledged to deliver are complete, and production-proven. The community has hammered away at the interfaces until they were ready for heavy-duty production usage.

This release signals that KitOps isn’t just a great idea, it’s a critical tool for today’s enterprise AI/ML teams.

A Note of Gratitude to Early Adopters

We owe a hefty round of applause to our early adopters and the community that rallied around the project. KitOps benefited immensely from user feedback from across the globe and in varied industries. Early adopters found KitOps a breeze to integrate with existing infrastructure—no new clusters, no hidden subscription fees, no forced migration to the trendiest cloud du jour. Being able to utilize existing security, access controls, and audit trails in OCI registries has been a game-changer, especially for organizations that care about data security, and regulated industries that need tight provenance and attestation measures.

As we celebrate this milestone in the KitOps journey, we invite you to download KitOps 1.0 today and slot it straight into your AI/ML development pipelines. We welcome new contributors—troublemakers, dreamers, and coders alike—to help shape our shared vision. Check out the GitHub repo, open an issue, or join our Discord community to speak your mind. Together, we’ll drive KitOps toward the future it deserves.

Kitops Project的Merry Manial Wariagers和贡献者很乐意宣布1.0版的Kitops发行。 Jozu在观察AI/ML包装和版本的碎片化导致的重大挑战之后，开始了Kitops项目。已提交给CNCF Sandbox的Kitops是一种开源包装和版本控制解决方案，旨在在各种计算环境中的速度，安全性和一致性。该工具为AI/ML从业人员提供了标准化的OCI伪像，称为ModelKit，利用广泛接受的OCI标准。这使组织能够有效地管理，安全和审核AI/ML项目。

奇特（Kitops）有一个宏伟的野心：加强数据科学家，应用程序开发人员和SRE之间的合作。因此，我们创建了围绕ModelKit的工具，以服务于所有这些组。 Kitops释放了一个名为Kit的CLI，该CLI用于台式机，管道和工具集成。我们还发布a github Action 和a 匕首模块用于AI/ML工作流程。对于数据科学家， pykitops 图书馆和新的 mlflow插件提供了一种简化的机制，可以将其作品分享作为其选择的任何OCI注册表上的模型套。

自推出以来，奇特已安装了超过45,000次，并被具有全球足迹和安全意识的公共部门开发团队的私人企业用于生产。

1.0中的新：拥抱脸导入或生成的Modelkits

奇特的一种常见用例正在组装一套安全且精心策划的基本模型，用于从拥抱面（如拥抱面）等第三方来源的内部消费。为了使它变得更加容易，套件CLI现在包括一个闪亮的新导入命令。将其指向一个拥抱的脸部存储库，然后 - presto！它生成了一个准备好从您的企业OCI注册表提供的ModelKit。

但是，您最喜欢的模特并不总是在拥抱的脸上举办。新的套件init命令自动扫描目录并生成Kitfile食谱。 Kitfile准确地指示CLI如何将所有内容包装到ModelKit中，以便您可以在几分钟内与其余的机组人员安全地共享您的AI/ML项目。

item.description:
【

The Notary Project maintainers are thrilled to announce the latest releases, including notation v1.3.0, notation-go v1.3.0, notation-core-go v1.2.0 and tspclient-go v1.0.0!

These new versions are production ready and have successfully completed a comprehensive security audit. Check out the security audit report for more details. Our commitment to providing secure and high-quality signing and verification tools for our users has never been stronger!

Notable Capabilities in these Releases

Here are the major capabilities and features included in these releases.

The first major release of tspclient-go library

Looking for a robust implementation of RFC 3161 Timestamp Protocol Client in Go? The library tspclient-go is the answer. Here is why:

  • RFC 3161 Compliance: Adheres to the specification RFC 3161 for timestamping clients. Supports timestamping with popular public TSAs like DigiCert and GlobalSign.
  • Secure: Implements secure communication protocols, ensuring the integrity and authenticity of timestamps.
  • Minimal Dependencies: Uses only standard Go libraries. Less dependencies, more secure.
  • High Test Coverage: Boasts up to 95% test coverage.
  • Security Audited: Passed a comprehensive security audit with no advisories, ensuring a high quality bar.
  • Ease of Use: Seamlessly integrates into Go applications with a straightforward API.

Notary Project’s timestamping feature is built on this library.

Certificate Revocation checking using Certificate Revocation List (CRL)

Certificate revocation checking enhances security by ensuring that compromised or expired certificates are not used, thereby maintaining the integrity and trustworthiness of digital signatures. It also helps organizations comply with security standards and regulations. With this release, Notation implements the Notary Project CRL specification with CRL cache support. Notation now supports two certificate revocation checking methods: Online Certificate Status Protocol (OCSP) and CRL. OCSP is preferred, but if unavailable, CRLs are used as a fallback. For more details on CRL cache directories, visit this link.

By default, Notary Project trust policies enforce revocation checking, so users do not need to configure it. For more details on fine-tuning revocation settings, visit this link.

Get started with Notation v1.3.0

You can follow the quick start guide to try Notation v1.3.0 for basic signing and verification workflow.

What’s next

The Notary Project maintainers are considering the following features for future milestones. Feel free to reach out on the Slack channel or GitHub issues to ask questions, provide feedback, or share ideas.

  • Sign and verify arbitrary blobs
  • Attestations

And more!

Acknowledgements

The Notary Project release team wants to thank the entire Notary Project community for all the activity and engagement that has been vital for helping the project grow and reach this milestone.

We are especially grateful to the CNCF for funding the security audit, the OSTIF for arranging it, and Quarkslab for conducting and releasing the audit report.

item.description:
【

Doubling down on open source, Mirantis invests further in the cloud native ecosystem

San Francisco, CA – January 30, 2025 – The Cloud Native Computing Foundation® (CNCF®), which builds sustainable ecosystems for cloud native software, today announced that Mirantis, which provides organizations with total control over their strategic infrastructure using open-source software, has upgraded its membership to Gold. 

Mirantis helps organizations accelerate time to value and simplify operations of modern workloads at scale wherever they are needed, by delivering Cloud Native open-source software to provide complete control over their strategic infrastructure. The company combines intelligent automation and cloud native expertise for managing and operating virtual machines, containers, Kubernetes, and cloud environments. 

“Having joined CNCF in 2016, Mirantis is deeply committed to the Kubernetes and CNCF ecosystems. As we double down on being a 100% pure play open source business, we are determined to invest further into these ecosystems,” said Randy Bias, vice president of open source strategy and technology, Mirantis. “For example, we deliver the 100% open source k0s CNCF-certified Kubernetes lightweight distribution. We will soon be announcing another new open source project that builds on top of our existing CNCF ecosystem projects that will help grow and enrich Kubernetes.” 

Having long-contributed to the Kubernetes project, every Mirantis product is Kubernetes-based or Kubernetes-related including enterprise products, Mirantis OpenStack on Kubernetes (MOSK) and Mirantis Kubernetes Engine (MKE). Mirantis also just recently moved to Harbor for Mirantis Secure Registry (MSR). 

A longtime proponent of open source, Mirantis is actively involved and contributes to more than 50 open source projects with efforts that are steered by the company’s Open Source Program Office directed by Bias. The company has also created several open source projects like k0s, the Mirantis certified Kubernetes distribution optimized for distributed edge workloads such as AI inference, and k0smotron, a Kubernetes control plane software, which are all broadly adopted. Mirantis also leverages numerous Graduated, Incubating, and Sandbox projects including OpenTelemetry, Project Sveltos, KubeVirt, Rook, Calico, Prometheus, and many others. 

“From very early on, Mirantis saw the importance of Kubernetes and CNCF and has been a valuable contributor to the cloud native ecosystem,” said Chris Anizczyk, CTO, CNCF. “Their move to become a Gold member is welcomed by CNCF and the community and we look forward to the team’s continued engagement and support.” 

At CNCF’s upcoming flagship conference KubeCon + CloudNativeCon Europe in London, happening 1–4 April, Mirantis has increased its sponsorship to the Gold level where it will display its latest open source innovations.

item.title: 【Announcing Ratify v1.4.0 – Revocation Checking with CRL Support, Enhanced Out-of-box Experience, and New Cloud Provider Support】宣布批准v1.4.0 - 撤销CRL支持，增强式盒装体验和新的云提供商支持的撤销检查
item.description:
【

We are thrilled to announce the release of Ratify v1.4.0! This milestone release introduces significant new features that enhance Ratify’s capabilities as a trusted supply chain security tool. As always, we deeply appreciate the contributions from the community, which make these advancements possible.

New Features

Revocation Checking with Certificate Revocation List (CRL) Support

Security in supply chain verification is critical, and this release marks an important step forward with the addition of revocation checking. Certificate revocation checking enhances security by ensuring that compromised or expired certificates are not used, thereby maintaining the integrity and trustworthiness of digital signatures. Ratify supports validating signing identity (certificate and certificate chain) revocation status. 

The CRL implementation uses Notation libraries and follows the Notary Project specification. Since Notation v1.3.0, Ratify users can now use revocation checking by default if your images are signed by Notation since CRL cache is enabled by default to enhance performance. It enables end-to-end revocation checking for validating image signature since reduced network traffic to the CRL server which minimizes potential server throttling and enhanced performance with lower latency. See Certificate Revocation Check (CRL) guidance for details.

Streamlined Notary Project Trust Policy Attributes in Helm Chart

To provide an out-of-the-box experience for users, this release adds more Notary Project trust policy attributes to the values.yaml of the Ratify Helm Chart. This enhancement addresses three major scenarios outlined in this issue, simplifying configuration and streamlining deployment processes for these common use cases:

  • The signed images are stored in a public registry
  • The signed images are stored in a private registry with certificates stored in AKV
  • The signed images are stored in a both public and private registry.

Alibaba Cloud RRSA Store Authentication Provider

Ratify community continues to expand its support for cloud-native ecosystems with the introduction of a new authentication provider for the Alibaba Cloud RRSA Store. Users leveraging Alibaba Cloud’s RRSA can now seamlessly integrate with Ratify, enabling secure artifact signing and verification within their workflows. This feature reflects our commitment to supporting a diverse and growing range of platforms in the cloud-native landscape. As a new partner of Ratify, Alibaba Cloud also created a guidance on how to use Ratify on Alibaba Cloud using Alibaba Cloud Container Service for Kubernetes (ACK) and Alibaba Cloud Container Registry (ACR).

Other enhancements

Image signing

Ratify official images are now signed by Notation and Cosign to ensure their integrity and authenticity. This helps defend against supply chain attacks by preventing tampered or untrusted images from being deployed in production environments. For more information, see the Signature Validation document.

Enhanced Diagnostic Experience

This release also adds timestamp and traceID in verification response to help users identity the failing request easily. The default constraint template is updated to report the timestamp and traceID when validation fails.

A Heartfelt Thanks to Our Contributors

Open-source projects thrive on the energy and dedication of their contributors. We are delighted to welcome five new contributors who have joined us in this release. Their efforts in refining the codebase, adding features, and addressing issues have been invaluable. To our new contributors: thank you for your hard work and passion for making Ratify better!

How to Get Started

To start exploring Ratify v1.4.0:

  • Check out the release notes for a detailed overview of changes and improvements.
  • Upgrade to the latest release by following the installation guide.
  • Provide feedback by opening issues or discussions on our GitHub repository.

Join the Ratify Community

Ratify’s growth is driven by an engaged and collaborative community. Whether you’re a developer, security professional, or just starting with supply chain security, we welcome your input and involvement. Join the community on our GitHub Discussions, Slack channel, community meeting, or share your ideas for improving Ratify.

Thank you for your continued support, and we look forward to hearing your feedback on this exciting release!

】

item.title: 【Advancing Open Source Gateways with kgateway】使用Kgateway推进开源网关
item.description:
【

At KubeCon NA 2024, Solo.io announced its intention to donate the Gloo Gateway open source project to the CNCF, to benefit the broader cloud native ecosystem. In case you are not familiar with Gloo Gateway, it is the most mature and widely deployed Envoy-based gateway in the market today. Built on open source and open standards, Gloo Gateway is Kubernetes-native and implements the Kubernetes Gateway API. Today, we’d like to update you on some exciting developments since the announcement.

What is a gateway, and why donate Gloo Gateway to CNCF?

If you are using Kubernetes, you most likely need a gateway to control traffic going into or out of your cluster. Gateways are a critical component of the Kubernetes ecosystem, which is why the Kubernetes community collectively developed the Gateway API based on lessons learned from the Ingress API and Istio. With the growth of AI workloads and the rising need for traffic and cost control for calling LLM providers, gateways play an even more critical role in controlling and securing all-direction traffic—north-south, east-west, or inter-service communication.

While Gloo Gateway is the most mature and feature-rich Envoy-based gateway today, we believe that under vendor-neutral governance, the project’s adoption and ecosystem integration will reach new heights. Donating the project to the CNCF will expand the contributor base, foster innovation across organizations, and provide a battle-tested, feature-rich, vendor-neutral gateway project to the diverse global CNCF user community.

Project Update

In November 2024, we moved the Gloo open source repository to the k8sgateway repository as a preparatory step for the donation. After working with the CNCF TOC, Kubernetes SIG-Network, and steering committee leaders, we renamed the project to kgateway.

Donation to CNCF

Given Gloo’s large adopter base, we believe kgateway qualifies as a CNCF incubation project. Due to the lengthy due diligence process for incubation projects, we decided to donate it as a CNCF sandbox project instead. We look forward to working with the CNCF TOC and TAG Network leaders for the upcoming sandbox review.

Open Governance

Working closely with the maintainer community, we established governance for the project that rewards maintainership while ensuring no single company has a controlling stake. Using the git-vote bot for transparency, we successfully held our first governance vote. Out of 10 eligible voters (including 4 maintainers outside Solo.io), nine voted favorably on the proposed governance PR:

Development focus

In addition to renaming the project, recruiting maintainers, and establishing governance, we’ve been focused on:

  1. Vendor Neutrality: Developing buildable, vendor-neutral artifacts, set to launch in the coming weeks.
  2. Improved Development Velocity: Establishing robust pipeline checks for PRs, including linting, Kubernetes Gateway API conformance tests, and end-to-end testing.
  3. Extensibility: Ensuring the project remains highly extendable, aligning with core design principles of kgateway and Envoy.

A shout-out to our core maintainers and contributors for laying this solid foundation for innovation.

Gloo Open Source Repo

You may notice that the Gloo open source repository still exists. This is temporary during the transition period. With Gloo’s large open source user base, we understand that migrating from Gloo to kgateway takes time. In upcoming releases, we plan to deprecate the Gloo repository to focus all open-source efforts on kgateway.

Kgateway Roadmap

We aim to make kgateway the most popular gateway for all-direction traffic—north-south, east-west, or inter-service communication. In addition to implementing the latest Kubernetes Gateway API features, we’re prioritizing:

Traffic control for AI workloads

As workloads like AI agents run on Kubernetes clusters, questions arise:

  • How securely do they connect to LLM services such as OpenAI or Gemini?
  • Are these services local or external, with usage-based costs?
  • How should credentials and backup LLMs be managed?
  • Do you want each developer to develop prompt guard and enrichment in their own AI workloads? 

Kgateway simplifies these challenges with two proposed declarative APIs for routing traffic to LLM providers while applying advanced policies such as secret management, backup LLMs, prompt guard or enrichment, and more. Refer to the enhancement proposal for more information.

The Gateway API Inference extension, sponsored by Kubernetes SIG-Network, focuses on extending the Kubernetes Gateway API with inference-specific routing extensions. It introduces the concept of an “InferencePool” (composed of one or more inference pods), enabling application developers to effectively route requests based on AI workload requirements. Daneyon Hanson has been leading our work for interference extensions and we are proud to see him nominated as a maintainer on the Gateway API Inference extension project as a result!

Providing advanced Layer 7 features for Istio in ambient mode

Ambient mode splits Istio functionality into a secure overlay layer (ztunnels) and a Layer 7 processing layer (waypoint). With kgateway as the waypoint proxy, users gain advanced L7 features such as request transformation, retries, and traffic control for AI workloads connecting to LLM services. This pluggability ensures consistent operational experiences for north-south and inter-service traffic. Steven Landow, who is a maintainer on both Istio and kgateway, is leading this effort.

To explore additional roadmap initiatives or propose updates, please refer to our roadmap document.

Get Involved

Are you interested in exploring kgateway, or are you already a Gloo Gateway user? We’d love to hear from you and shape the future of kgateway together. If working on cutting-edge cloud-native projects excites you, join us as a contributor! Connect with us via:

  • CNCF Slack (#kgateway channel)
  • Community meetings
  • Our GitHub repository

Let’s work together and build kgateway into the future of cloud connectivity!

】

在Kubecon NA 2024， solo.io宣布其意图捐赠 Gloo Gateway开源项目到CNCF，以使较宽的云本机生态系统受益。如果您不熟悉Gloo Gateway，它是当今市场上最成熟且最广泛部署的特使网关。 Gloo Gateway建立在开源和开放标准上，是Kubernetes-native，并实现了Kubernetes Gateway API。今天，我们想向您介绍以来公告以来的一些激动人心的发展。

什么是门户，为什么要捐赠Gloo Gateway到CNCF？

如果您使用的是kubernetes，则很可能需要一个网关来控制进入或群集中的流量。网关是Kubernetes生态系统的关键组成部分，这就是为什么Kubernetes社区共同开发了 Gateway api 从入口API和ISTIO中。随着AI工作负载的增长以及对致电LLM提供商的流量和成本控制的不断增长，Gateways在控制和确保全向流量（北方，东部，东西方或服务间沟通）中起着更为关键的作用。

虽然Gloo Gateway是当今最成熟且功能丰富的特使Gateway，但我们相信，在供应商中立的治理下，该项目的采用和生态系统集成将达到新的高度。将该项目捐赠给CNCF将扩大贡献者基础，跨组织促进创新，并为多元化的全球CNCF用户社区提供经过战斗的，功能丰富的供应商，中立的网关项目。

。

项目更新

在2024年11月，我们将Gloo开源存储库移至K8Sgateway存储库，以此作为捐赠的准备步骤。在与CNCF TOC，Kubernetes Sig-Network和指导委员会负责人合作之后，我们将该项目更名为 kgateway 。

。

向CNCF捐赠

鉴于Gloo的大型采用者基础，我们认为Kgateway有资格成为CNCF孵化项目。由于孵化项目的长期尽职调查过程，我们决定将其作为CNCF Sandbox Project 而不是捐赠。我们期待与CNCF TOC和标签网络负责人合作，以进行即将进行的Sandbox评论。

开放治理

与维护者社区紧密合作，我们为该项目建立了治理，该项目奖励了维护所有权，同时确保没有一家公司拥有控制股份。使用Git-Vote机器人进行透明度，我们成功举行了首次治理投票。在10名合格选民（包括Solo.io以外的4位维护者）中，有9个对 Propoped治理PR ：

开发焦点

除了重命名项目，招募维护者并建立治理外，我们还专注于：

  1. 供应商中立性：开发可建造的，供应商 - 中立工件，将在未来几周内推出。
  2. 提高了开发速度：建立PRS的强大管道检查，包括伸长，Kubernetes Gateway API符合测试和端到端测试。
  3. 可扩展性：确保项目保持高度扩展，与Kgateway和Envoy的核心设计原理保持一致。

向我们的核心维护者和为创新奠定坚实基础的贡献者大喊大叫。

gloo开源repo

您可能会注意到Gloo开源存储库仍然存在。这是过渡期间的临时性。借助Gloo的大型开源用户群，我们了解到从Gloo迁移到Kgateway需要时间。在即将发布的版本中，我们计划将Gloo存储库贬低，将所有开源工作集中在Kgateway上。

Kgateway路线图

我们的目标是使Kgateway成为全向交通的最受欢迎的门户 - 西南，东西方或服务间交流。除了实施最新的Kubernetes Gateway API功能外，我们还优先考虑：

AI工作负载的流量控制

作为像AI代理这样的工作负载，在Kubernetes群集上运行，问题出现：

  • 它们如何安全地连接到LLM服务，例如OpenAI或Gemini？
  • 这些服务是本地还是外部的，具有基于用法的成本？
  • 应如何管理凭证和备份LLM？
  • 您是否希望每个开发人员在自己的AI工作量中开发及时的警卫和丰富？ 

Kgateway通过提出的两个声明性API来简化这些挑战，以将流量路由到LLM提供商，同时应用秘密管理，备份LLMS，及时的警卫或富裕等高级政策。有关更多信息

Gateway API推断扩展，由Kubernetes Sig-network赞助，重点是扩展Kubernetes具有特定于推理的路由扩展的网关API。它介绍了“推入”的概念（由一个或多个推理POD组成），使应用程序开发人员能够根据AI工作负载要求有效地路由请求。 Daneyon Hanson一直在领导我们的工作进行干预延伸，我们很自豪地看到他被提名为维护者的维护者结果，网关API推断扩展项目结果！

在环境模式下为ISTIO提供高级层的功能

环境模式将ISTIO功能拆分为安全的覆盖层（ZTUNNELS）和7层处理层（WayPoint）。以Kgateway为Waypoint代理，用户可以获得高级L7功能，例如请求转换，重试和连接到LLM服务的AI工作负载。这种可实现的性能确保了南北和服务际交通的一致运营经验。史蒂文·兰多（Steven Landow）是ISTIO和KGATEWAWA的维护者，他正在领导这项工作。

item.title: 【Digital transformation driven by community: Kubernetes as example】由社区驱动的数字化转型：库伯纳特作为例如
item.description:
【

Member post by Angel Ramirez, Cuemby

In a rapidly evolving technological landscape, Kubernetes emerges as a transformative force in open-source innovation. Originating from a Google project in 2014, it has grown into a global movement that revolutionizes how businesses approach scalability and cloud infrastructure. Beyond being merely a tool, Kubernetes symbolizes the strength of collaboration, enabling organizations to navigate the complexities of modern application deployment with ease. 

How does Kubernetes continually reshape industries? The continuous evolution of Kubernetes is driven by its vibrant community of contributors worldwide. This collaborative spirit allows Kubernetes to adapt and respond to diverse industry challenges, empowering businesses to innovate and maintain a competitive edge. With capabilities such as automated scaling, service discovery, and storage orchestration, Kubernetes simplifies the management of containerized applications, allowing developers to focus on delivering value rather than grappling with infrastructure issues. 

As we delve deeper into the world of Kubernetes, it becomes clear that the future of digital transformation may rely not just on technological advancements but also on the collective intelligence of global communities. Kubernetes orchestrates more than just containers; it fosters a mindset where adaptability and teamwork are paramount, paving the way for lasting impacts in the tech landscape.

The Kubernetes Community: A Catalyst for Transformation

In 2024, Kubernetes has solidified its position as a cornerstone of modern cloud infrastructure, marking a decade of remarkable growth and innovation since its inception. With over 88,000 contributors from more than 8,000 companies across 44 countries, Kubernetes has become the second-largest open-source project globally, reflecting the immense collaborative effort that has shaped its evolution (Kubernetes.io Blog, 2024). The Cloud Native Computing Foundation (CNCF) reports that Kubernetes adoption has surged, with 96% of enterprises now utilizing the platform, showcasing its critical role in contemporary IT architecture and operations (Edge Delta, 2024). 

As organizations increasingly adopt Kubernetes (Google, Microsoft, IBM, Amazon, Apple, Netflix, Spotify, Airbnb, Salesforce, Zalando, Lyft, Red Hat, Shopify, Slack, Udemy, Pinterest, Booking.com, Druva, Pure Storage Inc., Deloitte), the list continues to grow infinitely as more organizations embrace this transformative technology. However, they are navigating both opportunities and challenges. 

A significant trend is the shift towards multi-cluster and multi-environment deployments. The average user now operates over 20 clusters, often across various environments such as cloud services and data centers. However, this complexity comes with hurdles; approximately 75% of businesses report that managing Kubernetes has been hampered by its inherent complexity and the scarcity of skilled talent. This paradox highlights the need for ongoing education and support within the community to ensure that organizations can fully leverage Kubernetes’ capabilities (Spectro Cloud, 2024).

Scaling and Innovating with Kubernetes

The true power of Kubernetes lies in its ability to enable scalable, resilient, and automated infrastructure. For companies, this translates into more efficient deployments, optimized resource management, and faster time to market. Kubernetes is the go-to platform for running not just traditional workloads but also next-gen technologies like AI, machine learning (ML), and high-performance computing (HPC).

As GenAI usage grows, Kubernetes is playing an increasingly critical role in supporting resource-intensive AI workloads. The adaptability and scalability of Kubernetes infrastructure allow businesses to handle massive data processing tasks and complex machine learning algorithms without the need for costly proprietary systems.

What truly excites me, as a CEO, Kubestronaut, and technologist, is how Kubernetes serves as a digital compass that guides organizations through the ever-evolving landscape of technology and business. By automating infrastructure management and accelerating application deployment, it liberates teams from the shackles of traditional IT constraints, allowing them to explore uncharted territories of innovation. This paradigm shift not only enhances operational efficiency but also cultivates a culture of experimentation and agility. In a world where the ability to pivot quickly can mean the difference between thriving and merely surviving, Kubernetes emerges as a transformative force—turning organizations into nimble explorers ready to navigate the complexities of the digital age and seize new opportunities as they arise.

Building a Cloud-Native Ecosystem: Collaboration Beyond Code

While Kubernetes is the centerpiece, the cloud-native ecosystem is growing rapidly, with a multitude of complementary projects that integrate seamlessly with it. Projects like Helm (for package management), Prometheus (for monitoring), and Envoy (for service meshes) have become critical to Kubernetes’ success. These tools work together to offer a comprehensive suite of technologies for organizations to manage, monitor, and scale their applications in the cloud.

What I find truly revolutionary is how Kubernetes has transformed our approach to software deployment. It transcends the traditional focus on managing individual applications; now, it’s about overseeing entire ecosystems of services that can be rapidly deployed, scaled, and dismantled on demand. This shift provides businesses with unparalleled flexibility and control over their resources. 

Moreover, the open-source nature of Kubernetes fosters a culture of collaboration and innovation, empowering companies to leverage these tools without the anxiety of vendor lock-in. By moving away from reliance on proprietary software, organizations can harness the collective expertise and resources of a global community, ensuring that their cloud-native strategies remain adaptable and resilient in an ever-changing technological landscape.

The Global Growth of Kubernetes: A Collaborative Effort

One of the most exciting developments in the Kubernetes ecosystem is its expanding global outreach, significantly supported by the Cloud Native Computing Foundation (CNCF). In 2024, we witnessed Kubernetes-related events proliferate into regions such as Australia and Zurich, which were previously underrepresented in the community (Source: CNCF, 2024). This surge in activity reflects a broader global effort to introduce cloud-native technologies to new markets and signifies a growing recognition of Kubernetes as an essential tool for modern infrastructure. 

Emerging markets in Latin America and Asia also experienced heightened engagement, with Kubernetes Community Days (KCD) taking place in cities like São Paulo, Costa Rica, and Dhaka (Source: CNCF, 2024). The increasing popularity of Kubernetes in these diverse regions underscores its transformation from a niche solution into the de facto platform for cloud-native operations worldwide. Notably, the total number of Kubernetes-related events rose from 29 in 2023 to 34 in 2024, indicating a robust increase in community engagement and outreach. 

This growth is fueled by local communities and regional leaders who play a vital role in nurturing talent and fostering innovation tailored to each region’s unique needs. The CNCF’s emphasis on regional outreach has led to more decentralized events, enhancing collaboration among developers and organizations. By supporting the development of local ecosystems, the CNCF and its partners are ensuring that Kubernetes adoption is not only widespread but also relevant and impactful across various cultural contexts. With over +110.000 Kubernetes-related job listings worldwide on LinkedIn as of 2025 and an anticipated market growth rate of 23.4% by 2031, the demand for skilled professionals in this technology is surging, reflecting its critical role across industries from tech to finance. As organizations increasingly recognize the value of Kubernetes, its integration with emerging technologies like AI and machine learning further solidifies its position as a cornerstone of modern infrastructure, paving the way for innovative solutions that can adapt to the complexities of tomorrow’s digital landscape.

The Human Element: A Critical Piece of the Puzzle

While Kubernetes is a technological marvel, its success lies in the people who contribute to its development, usage, and ongoing evolution. The community has created a culture of sharing knowledge, helping one another, and collectively driving progress. From developers contributing code to organizations deploying Kubernetes at scale, the community has been the backbone of Kubernetes’ growth.

For me, one of the most valuable lessons is that technology alone does not drive transformation—people do. Building a strong community around a technology is just as important as building the technology itself. item.description:
【

Member post originally published on the Devtron blog by Siddhant Khisty

TL;DR: Devtron simplifies application promotion across environments by enhancing CI/CD pipelines with GitOps. It supports seamless deployments, easy rollbacks, approval policies and audit logs, making software delivery more reliable and efficient.

In the constantly evolving landscape of building and deploying applications, continuous integration (CI) and continuous deployment (CD) pipelines have played a crucial role in ensuring that software is built, tested, and deployed reliably. Traditional pipelines included building the application’s executable binary files and deploying them to a VM.

However, the entire DevOps landscape transforms fundamentally as organizations move towards a cloud-native system, with Kubernetes at the forefront. While Kubernetes addresses many of the challenges with scaling applications, it also introduces its own set of complexities and challenges. With the addition of GitOps, the entire CI and CD landscape becomes even more complex.

Moreover, within cloud-native environments, the application usually needs to be deployed across multiple environments, such as dev, QA, UAT, and production. GitOps tools such as ArgoCD can sync the cluster’s state with the state defined within the Git repository. However, they fail to promote the application across multiple environments. 

Devtron has introduced a new feature that allows you to progressively promote your applications across different environments seamlessly while ensuring that all the necessary checks have passed. Before diving more into the intricacies of how Devtron can help you promote applications, let’s understand the need for application promotion.

What is Application Promotion?

Application promotion is the process of progressively deploying an application through the different environments of the software deployment pipeline, such as the development, QA, staging, and production environments. This progression of the application through multiple environments helps ensure that the application runs smoothly and that the features and changes are thoroughly validated through multiple environments. The application can progress to the next environment after meeting certain requirements such as passing test cases.

In a cloud-native application, multiple microservices need to be deployed in a scalable and flexible way. Promoting the application across multiple environments can help simplify the delivery of these microservices while keeping CI/CD as the base. It can also fill the gaps between the CI and CD pipelines to accelerate the software delivery process. The promotion process can be customized to fit your particular use cases.

By promoting the application across all these different environments, you can reduce the risk of facing any potential errors in the application, or misconfigurations, and safeguard against downtime, hence increasing the production stability. This is all possible as the application is deployed and validated across multiple environments before it can ever reach the production environment. Ultimately it helps improve deployment reliability and efficiency by making the deployment more predictable and maintaining a consistent state across environments.

By adopting the application promotion process, several benefits are experienced across the entire CI/CD and GitOps pipelines. Some of these benefits include:

  • Improved flexibility and control over deployment pipelines
  • Vigorous testing of the application across different environments to ensure that the release to production is stable
  • Adopting application promotion helps manage the complexities of multi-environment deployments.
  • Enforces standardized practices across the deployment process
  • Allows teams to quickly identify bottlenecks and optimize the deployment process.

Limitations of traditional CI/CD

The traditional approach to CI/CD pipelines was straightforward: building, testing, and then deploying the application to the production environment. However, with modern approaches to application deployment, this linear process falls short, as the application has numerous different microservices that have separate build pipelines. The entire application cannot be tested properly until all the microservers are present and running. 

To test the application properly, the services must be deployed to a testing environment, which should be handled by the CD pipeline. Once the application tests pass in the testing environment, certain tests need to be performed to ensure that the application can work under load, for which dummy traffic has to be emulated. After the tests across all these different environments have succeeded, the application is then finally deployed to the production environment. 

The traditional CI/CD process falls short, as the idea was simply to follow a streamlined approach without considering that the application will have to be deployed and validated across multiple different environments.

Moreover, to compensate for the gaps of traditional CI/CD, the CI tools are being overused, even outside the scope of the CI pipelines. Instead of simply handling build talks, CI systems are being used for deployment and promoting the applications to other environments using custom scripting. As the CI tools are not designed to be deployment systems, they fall short in multiple areas for deployment.

While traditional CI and CD mechanisms have worked for legacy systems, they do fall short in several ways when it comes to modern cloud-native systems. Some of the key challenges that one might face include:

  • Traditional CI and CD pipelines were built for a linear build, test, and deploy approach for deploying applications. This introduced challenges when you wish to deploy to multiple environments and progressively promote the application
  • The CI pipeline is often overused well beyond the scope of Continuous Integration. Organizations write custom scripts to deploy the application as well as progressively promote it across the environments. 
  • Managing versions for the different microservices and environmental configurations becomes a challenge, as each environment has its own unique configurations.
  • The traditional process also relies heavily on integrating external tools for monitoring and triggering rollbacks, which leads to a tool sprawl, further increasing the deployment complexities.

Challenges with Application Promotion

Promoting an application across multiple different environments has several different challenges associated with it. As we have discussed earlier, many CI systems that are not designed for deployments, are being overused to deploy and promote the application to different environments. This process can be quite error-prone as custom scripts have to be used. The custom scripts may not satisfy all the required conditions and test cases. Additionally, there is no way to trigger a rollback if the deployment has bugs or any error occurs.

As the number of environments scales, the complexity increases as well. There are many environments which the application will have to be promoted through. Some phases may even require you to deploy the application to two environments parallelly. Additionally, there needs to be some governance around these promotions. The application should not be deployed to an environment without explicit approval from the relevant stakeholders.

There also needs to be a proper audit log to track the deployments that have been triggered on each environment, along with their configurations. Managing the configurations across the different environments is also a challenge as the configurations of production are going to be different compared to configurations of environments such as dev or staging.

To sum it up, some of the key challenges that organizations face while trying to promote the applications across different environments include:

  • The lack of quick rollback mechanisms for triggering rollbacks in case of application failures in any of the environments.
  • Setting up approval gates for multiple environments requires integrating external tools and frameworks which leads to additional tool overhead and added complexity.
  • As the number of environments increases, the complexity of promoting the application increases as well. Existing deployment systems fall short when deploying and promoting the application across the environments.
  • The lack of a proper audit log makes it difficult to figure out which team triggered a deployment and the configurations that the application is deployed with.
  • During the promotion process, every environment has its own configurations. Maintaining unique configurations for each environment and updating as needed can become challenging. Moreover, you may want to prevent updating the configurations from being updated without proper approval.

Application Promotion in Devtron

Devtron is an open-source Kubernetes management platform that helps abstract the entire CI/CD process. It can help create the build (CI) and deployment (CD) pipelines and seamlessly connect them. Devtron can also allow you to create multiple deployment environments and deploy your applications to different environments either sequentially or parallelly.

In the above image, you can see that the web app is being built and first being deployed to the utils environment and parallelly, it is also deployed to the devtron-demo environment. If all the checks in the utils environment pass, the application will get promoted to the staging environment and subsequently to the production environment. Devtron also allows you to apply an approval policy to the different deployments. In case of any failures, Devtron allows for an easy one-click rollback.

Devtron also stores an entire audit log of the deployments that have been triggered across the different environments. You can see all the deployments that have been triggered along with their status, environment-specific configurations, and more. In the below image, you can see the latest deployment for the prod environment. Similarly, you can filter through the different environments that are configured for this particular application.

Managing the configurations for all the different environments can easily become overwhelming and you might end up using the wrong configurations in a specific environment. Devtron streamlines the configuration process and let’s you define the configuration for each environment. You can also lock the configurations, and without approval from the authorized stakeholders, the configurations for the environment cannot be changed.

Many times, organizations might have different teams for handling deployments to different environments. In this case, the environment access has to be restricted to the specific team members. Devtron has robust RBAC capabilities will will let you fine-grain the level of access operations teams have to specific environments. You can set up the RBAC permissions, for each individual environment. Instead of having to apply the same permissions for every single user, you can create a permission group that lets you assign the same set of permissions for all users in a particular team. Please check out the following blog to learn about Devtron’s robust RBAC framework.

Conclusion

Application Promotion can help mitigate any deployment errors well before the application reaches production environments. During the entire deployment process, the application is vigorously tested across multiple different environments to ensure that it functions properly without any errors. 

With Devtron, you can create enterprise grade CI and CD pipelines that follow the GitOps principles and allow you to progressively promote the application across multiple environments. To ensure that only authorized individuals can trigger the deployment or change the environment specific configurations, Devtron also has robust approval policies and RBAC.  Additonally, Devtron provides an entire audit log for viewing the deployment history, along with the configurations across all the environments in the pipeline.

CI/CD管道的传统方法很简单：建筑，测试，然后将应用程序部署到生产环境中。但是，借助现代应用程序部署方法，该线性过程不足，因为该应用程序具有许多不同的微服务，这些微服务具有单独的构建管道。在所有微观器都存在和运行之前，无法正确测试整个应用程序。 

要正确测试应用程序，必须将服务部署到测试环境中，该测试环境应由CD管道处理。一旦应用程序测试通过测试环境，就需要执行某些测试，以确保应用程序可以在负载下工作，必须对此进行模拟。在所有这些不同环境中的测试成功之后，该应用程序最终被部署到生产环境中。 

传统的CI/CD进程不足，因为这个想法只是遵循简化的方法，而无需考虑必须在多个不同环境中部署和验证应用程序。

此外，为了弥补传统CI/CD的差距，CI工具被过度使用，甚至在CI管道范围之外。与其简单地处理构建谈判，CI系统被用于部署和使用自定义脚本促进应用程序。由于CI工具不是设计为部署系统的，因此它们不足E部署区域。

虽然传统的CI和CD机制在传统系统上起作用，但在现代云本地系统方面，它们确实以多种方式跌落。人们可能面临的一些主要挑战包括：

  • 传统的CI和CD管道是为部署应用程序的线性构建，测试和部署方法而设计的。当您希望部署到多种环境并逐步推广应用程序
    • 时，这引入了挑战。
  • CI管道通常超出了连续整合的范围。组织编写自定义脚本以部署应用程序以及在整个环境中逐步推广它。 
  • 为不同的微服务和环境配置管理版本成为一个挑战，因为每个环境都有其独特的配置。
  • 传统过程还很大程度上依赖于整合用于监视和触发回滚的外部工具，这会导致工具蔓延，进一步提高了部署复杂性。

应用程序促销

挑战

在多个不同环境中促进应用程序具有与之相关的几个不同的挑战。正如我们之前讨论的那样，许多不是为部署而设计的CI系统，他们被过度使用以部署和促进应用程序到不同环境的应用。由于必须使用自定义脚本，因此此过程可能非常容易出错。自定义脚本可能无法满足所有必需的条件和测试用例。此外，如果部署有错误或发生任何错误，则无法触发回滚。

作为环境尺度的数量，复杂性也会增加。应用程序必须通过许多环境进行促进。一些阶段甚至可能要求您将应用程序部署到两个环境中。此外，需要围绕这些促销活动有一些治理。未经相关利益相关者的明确批准，不应将申请部署到环境中。

还需要有适当的审核日志，以跟踪在每个环境上触发的部署以及它们的配置。在不同环境中管理配置也是一个挑战，因为与开发或舞台等环境的配置相比，生产的配置将不同。

。

总结一下，组织在试图在不同环境中推广应用程序时面临的一些关键挑战包括：

  • 缺乏在任何环境中应用程序故障的情况下触发回滚的快速回滚机制。
  • 为多种环境设置批准门需要集成外部工具和框架会导致其他工具开销并增加了复杂性。
  • 随着环境数量的增加，促进应用程序的复杂性也会增加。现有部署系统在部署和促进整个环境中的应用程序时都缺乏。
  • 缺乏适当的审核日志使得很难弄清楚哪个团队触发了部署以及应用程序部署的配置。
  • 在促销过程中，每个环境都有自己的配置。为每个环境保持独特的配置并根据需要进行更新可能会变得具有挑战性。此外，您可能需要防止在未经适当批准的情况下更新配置。

devtron中的应用程序促销

Devtron是一个开源Kubernetes管理平台，可帮助抽象整个CI/CD流程。它可以帮助创建构建（CI）和部署（CD）管道，并无缝连接它们。 Devtron还可以允许您创建多个部署环境，并将应用程序依次或相相部署到不同的环境。

在上图中，您可以看到Web应用程序正在构建，并首先部署到 utils 环境和可行性，也将部署到 devtron-demo 环境。如果 utils 环境通过中的所有检查，则该应用程序将升级为 staging 环境，然后将其升级为生产环境。 Devtron还允许您将批准政策应用于不同的部署。如果发生任何故障，Devtron允许轻松的一键回滚。

devtron还存储了在不同环境中触发的部署的整个审核日志。您可以看到所有已触发的部署以及其状态，特定于环境的配置等。在下图中，您可以看到针对产品环境的最新部署。同样，您可以通过为此特定应用程序配置的不同环境过滤。

管理所有不同环境的配置很容易变得压倒性而且您可能最终在特定环境中使用错误的配置。 Devtron简化了配置过程，让您为每个环境定义配置。您也可以锁定配置，未经授权利益相关者的批准，无法更改环境的配置。

多次，组织可能有不同的团队来处理在不同环境中的部署。在这种情况下，环境访问必须仅限于特定的团队成员。 Devtron具有强大的RBAC功能，将使您允许您对特定环境的访问操作级别进行细化。您可以为每个环境设置RBAC权限。您不必为每个用户应用相同的权限，而是可以创建一个权限组，使您可以为特定团队中的所有用户分配相同的权限集。请查看以下博客以了解 devtron's”强大的RBAC框架 。

item.title: 【KCD Austria 2024: a celebration of cloud native 🌐🎬】KCD奥地利2024年：庆祝云原住民🌐🎬
item.description:
【

The lights dimmed, the screen lit up, and the atmosphere was nothing short of electric. KCD Austria 2024 took place in the heart of Vienna, transforming a classic cinema into a hub of cloud native innovation and community spirit. This year’s event was more than just a conference; it was a testament to the growth and passion of the cloud native community in Austria.

Growing our Community with Cloud Native Austria 🇦🇹

The community members who organized KCD Austria are thrilled to announce they have organized as Cloud Native Austria, a community-operated association born with the sole purpose of hosting KCD Austria and organizing cloud native communities across the country. This community-run non-profit organization symbolizes our commitment to fostering collaboration, sharing knowledge, and nurturing the next generation of cloud native enthusiasts in partnership with CNCF.

Below is an exciting update from the organizers and leadership of Cloud Native Austria.

The Venue: Where Cinema Meets Cloud Native 🎥

Returning to the same iconic cinema as last year, we embraced the unique ambiance that only a movie theater can offer. The plush seats, the immersive screen, and the surround sound created an unparalleled setting for learning and networking. The venue wasn’t just a backdrop; it was an integral part of the KCD Austria experience.

With the talks taking place in two dedicated rooms, as well as having a whole floor for food, coffee and our valued sponsors, we provided enough space to mingle and connect. We even had full size sofas for the first row audience – how cool is that! 🛋️

Celebrating Our Exceptional Speakers 🎤

Our lineup boasted an incredible array of talent, featuring both seasoned experts and fresh voices in the cloud native sphere. Renowned veterans like Juraci Paixão Kröhling shared invaluable insights, enriching the discussions with their extensive experience. We were equally excited to also welcome first-time speakers, e.g. a student team from TU Wien, including Lukas Mahler, Tobias Grantner, and Josef Taha, who brought new perspectives and innovative ideas to the forefront.

The agenda covered a broad spectrum of topics, ranging from thought-provoking non-technical talks that delved into the cultural and organizational aspects of cloud native adoption, to deep-dive security sessions that equipped attendees with the latest strategies to protect their infrastructures. This diversity not only catered to a wide audience but also fostered a holistic understanding of the cloud native landscape.

You can find all our amazing speakers here.

Audience Favorites and Feedback 🌟

Some talks resonated exceptionally well with our audience:

  • “Failing Successfully“ by Stefan Baumgartner
  • “Forensic Container Checkpointing and Analysis“ by Adrian Reber
  • “The kubectl debug command is missing an IDE option.” by Mario Loriedo
  • “Demystifying CRI – Writing a CRI from Scratch“ by Filip Nikolic

You can find a recording of each talk on our YouTube channel: KCD Austria.

Our sessions received outstanding feedback, with over 75% of the 102 feedback responses rating the talks 4 or 5 out of 5 stars. This positive response is a testament to the quality and relevance of the content delivered.

We also value your constructive feedback and have heard your suggestions. Next time, we plan to offer longer sessions to provide more in-depth content. Additionally, we will introduce experience level tags for each talk, helping attendees select sessions that best match their knowledge and interests.

Highlights of KCD Austria 2024 ✨

  • Second Edition Success: Building on the momentum from 2023, we brought the same spirit to this year’s event.
  • Overwhelming Response: We received over 200 submissions in the Call for Proposals, showcasing the community’s eagerness to contribute.
  • Diverse Content: Featuring 40 speakers, 24 talks, and 4 workshops, attendees had a wealth of sessions to choose from.
  • Growing Audience: With about 30% more attendees than last year, we reached the maximum capacity of our beloved venue.

For an in-depth look at our event, check out our transparency report.

Lessons Learned 📚

  1. Embracing Sessionize: Switching our Call for Proposals to Sessionize made the process enjoyable and efficient, a stark contrast to last year’s tool.
  2. Leveraging Experience: Utilizing templates and insights from 2023 streamlined our planning and execution.
  3. Team Dynamics: Clear communication and commitment within the team and with external partners were crucial.
  4. Role Clarity: Having one overall key organizer and dedicated roles for each other team member is mandatory for smooth operations.
  5. Professional Tools: Investing in professional tools paid off, significantly outweighing the costs in terms of efficiency.
  6. Valuable Retrospectives: Conducting a retrospective allowed us to gather structured feedback and share experiences from both organizer and volunteer perspectives.

Looking Ahead: Cloud Native Days Austria 2025 🚀

As we set our sights on the future, we’re excited to announce that we will continue our journey as Cloud Native Days Austria, an independent event that maintains a close relationship with the CNCF and the global community.

  • Save the Date: October 2025 in Vienna.
  • Evolving Team: Some of our organizers will pursue new goals, and while our team may shrink, it will also evolve.
  • Continued Collaboration: Our local CNCF community chapters in Austria will proceed as usual, strengthening the bonds within our cloud native family.

A Heartfelt Thank You 🙏

  • To all KCD Austria Organizers and Volunteers: Your dedication and hard work made this event possible.
  • To all KCD Austria Sponsors and Media Partners: Your support was instrumental in bringing KCD Austria 2024 to life.
  • To the CNCF: Thank you for your continuous guidance and for fostering a global community that inspires us.

Stay connected with us for updates on future events and join us as we continue to champion cloud native technologies in Austria and beyond.

Let’s keep the cloud native spirit alive! See you in 2025! 🎉

】

灯光变暗，屏幕亮了，气氛简直是电。 KCD奥地利2024年发生在维也纳的心脏地带，将经典电影院变成了云原住民创新和社区精神的枢纽。今年的活动不仅仅是会议。这证明了奥地利云土著社区的成长和热情。

与云原住民奥地利建立我们的社区🇦🇹

组织KCD奥地利的社区成员很高兴地宣布，他们已经组织为 云一个社区经营的协会，其唯一目的是在全国范围内举办KCD奥地利和组织云土著社区。这个社区经营的非营利组织象征着我们与CNCF合作培养合作，共享知识和培养下一代云的本地爱好者的承诺。

以下是云原住民奥地利组织者和领导的令人兴奋的更新。

> 地点：电影院遇到云的地方

回到去年的标志性电影院时，我们接受了只有电影院才能提供的独特氛围。毛绒座椅，沉浸式屏幕和周围的声音为学习和网络创造了无与伦比的设置。场地不仅仅是背景。这是KCD奥地利体验不可或缺的一部分。

在两个专门的房间里进行了会谈，并拥有整个食物，咖啡和我们有价值的赞助商的地板，我们提供了足够的空间来混合和连接。我们甚至为第一行观众提供了全尺寸的沙发 - 那真是太酷了！ 🛋️

庆祝我们的杰出演讲者

我们的阵容拥有令人难以置信的才华横溢，在云本地球体中都有经验丰富的专家和新鲜的声音。著名的退伍军人，例如JuraciPaixãoKröhling分享了宝贵的见解，以其丰富的经验丰富了讨论。我们也很高兴也欢迎首次演讲者，例如来自 tu Wien 的学生团队，包括 Lukas Mahler ， Tobias Grantner 和 Josef Taha ，他带来了新的观点和创新的想法到最前沿。

议程涵盖了各种各样的主题，从发人深省的非技术谈判中，深入研究云土著采用的文化和组织方面，到为参与者提供最新策略的深入探讨，以保护他们基础设施。这种多样性不仅满足了广泛的听众，而且还培养了对云原生景观的整体理解。

受众最爱和反馈

一些谈话与我们的听众异常引起共鸣：

  • “ 成功失败 Stefan Baumgartner
  • “ form> formang> forensic container chancepter和分析 “ Adrian Reber
  • “ 。” Mario Loriedo
  • “ demysifying cri - 从scratch 撰写CRI “ filip nikolic

您可以在我们的YouTube频道上找到每次演讲的录音： KCD奥地利。

我们的会议收到了出色的反馈， 102的反馈响应超过75％ 评级谈话 4或5颗星中的5星。这种积极的反应证明了所交付内容的质量和相关性。

我们还重视您的建设性反馈，并听到了您的建议。下次，我们计划提供更长的会议，以提供更深入的内容。此外，我们将为每次演讲介绍体验级别标签，帮助与会者选择最适合其知识和兴趣的会议。

KCD奥地利2024

的亮点
  • 第二版成功：在2023年的动力上，我们为今年的活动带来了同样的精神。
  • 压倒性的回应：我们在呼吁提案中收到了200份提交的意见，展示了社区渴望贡献的渴望。
  • 多样的内容：具有 40扬声器， 24谈话和 4个研讨会，与会者有很多会议可供选择。
  • 不断增长的受众：与去年相比，参与者大约增加了30％，我们达到了我们心爱的场地的最大容量。

要了解我们的活动，请查看我们的透明度报告 。

经验教训

  1. 拥抱sessionize ：将我们提出建议的呼吁 sessionize 使该过程愉快而有效，与之形成了鲜明的对比去年的工具。
  2. 利用经验：利用2023年的模板和见解简化了我们的计划和执行。
  3. 团队动态：团队内部的清晰沟通和承诺和外部合作伙伴至关重要。
  4. 角色清晰度：为彼此的团队成员拥有一个整体关键的组织者和敬业的角色。
  5. 专业工具：投资已还清的专业工具，大大超过了效率的成本。
  6. 有价值的回顾：进行回顾使我们能够收集结构化的反馈并分享从组织者和志愿者的观点分享经验。

向前看：云原住民奥地利2025

当我们对未来的目光开明时，我们很高兴地宣布，我们将继续我们的旅程，因为云云原住民奥地利，这是一个与CNCF和CNCF和The The CNCF保持密切关系的独立事件地球al社区。

  • 保存日期：2025年10月在维也纳。
  • 不断发展的团队：我们的一些组织者将追求新的目标，尽管我们的团队可能会缩小，但它也会发展。
  • 继续合作：我们在奥地利的当地CNCF社区章节将照常进行，增强我们云原住民的纽带。

您可以找到我们所有惊人的扬声器在这里。

item.title: 【Japan’s CNCF DevStats 2024】日本的CNCF Devstats 2024
item.description:
【

Hello, we are Toru Komatsu (@utam0k) and Hiroshi Hayakawa (@hhiroshell) from Cloud Native Community Japan. The Japanese version is available below.

Have you heard of CNCF’s DevStats? DevStats is a tool that collects and quantifies all contributions to CNCF projects from GitHub. By leveraging this data, you can analyze development activities within CNCF projects from various perspectives.

One key metric is Contribution, which quantifies activities such as reviews, comments, commits, issues, and pull requests (PRs) on GitHub. This metric allows you to objectively assess a project’s contribution levels. Additionally, contributions can be aggregated by country, individual, and other perspectives.

In this article, we use DevStats data from 2024 to focus on individual contributions in Japan and examine the impact Japanese engineers made throughout the year.

Top 10 Contributors in CNCF Projects

This time, we introduce the top 10 Japanese contributors with the highest Contribution scores from the five CNCF Graduated projects with the most Japanese contributors.

Note

  • Except for Kubernetes, Contribution is aggregated across the entire GitHub organization of each project.
  • Company affiliations are based on information from cncf/gitdm and may not reflect the actual affiliation.

Kubernetes

Since contributions to the Kubernetes GitHub organization include many non-code activities such as translations, we present the data separately for the kubernetes/kubernetes repository and the overall Kubernetes organization.

Kubernetes had the highest number of contributors from Japan, with a total of 93 contributors.

fluentd

Three contributors to fluentd achieved Contribution scores of 1,000 or more, among the highest worldwide for Fluentd.

Argo

In Argo, the top contributor, yu-croco, stood out significantly. While the total Contribution score was not particularly high, a notable aspect was the number of contributors from Japan, which reached 23—more than in other CNCF Graduated projects.

Containerd

In Containerd, akihirosuda, who was awarded CNCF Top Committer in 2023, recorded an outstanding Contribution score. His score of 4,392 was the highest among all contributors worldwide.

Cilium

Cilium, which graduated in 2023, ranked as the 5th most contributed-to project by Japanese developers in 2024. This result reflects the growing attention and momentum Cilium has gained in Japan.

Top 20 Contributors in CNCF

Finally, here are the top 20 Japanese contributors based on Number across all CNCF projects.

Conclusion

By analyzing DevStats data, we can quantify the contributions of developers supporting CNCF projects. Their efforts play a vital role in sustaining CNCF every day. We hope that highlighting their contributions in this blog will motivate them.

This is the first year we have conducted this analysis, and we look forward to seeing how things evolve in 2025. Continuous tracking will provide more meaningful insights over time. Notably, KubeCon + CloudNativeCon Japan 2025 will take place next year, and we hope this conference will further encourage contributions from Japan.Additionally, some contributors may find that their listed company may be outdated or incorrect or that they are not appearing in the rankings despite residing in Japan and actively contributing. These details can be updated via cncf/gitdm.

—

こんにちは Cloud Native Community Japan の Toru Komatsu(@utam0k) と Hiroshi Hayakawa(@hhiroshell) です。

CNCF の DevStats をご存知ですか？DevStats はCNCF Project でのあらゆる貢献活動を GitHub から集計し、数値化しているツールです。このデータを活用することで、CNCF Project で行われている開発活動を様々な観点で分析できます。

中でも Contribution という指標は、GitHub 上でのレビュー、コメント、コミット、Issue、Pull Request（PR）による貢献を数値化したものです。この指標を活用することで、プロジェクトへの貢献度を定量的に把握できます。また、Contribution は国別や個人別など、さまざまな切り口で集計することも可能です。

本記事では、2024 年の日本における DevStats のデータをもとに、特に個人の貢献に焦点を当てて紹介します。日本のエンジニアたちが 2024 年にどのような活躍をしたのか、その足跡をここで振り返ります。

CNCF プロジェクトでの Top 10

今回は、CNCF Graduated プロジェクトの中で日本の貢献者数が多い上位 5 プロジェクトから、特に Contribution が高い 10 名を紹介します。

Note

  • Kubernetesを除き、プロジェクトの GitHub organizaiton 全体の Contribution を集計しています
  • Companyはcncf/gitdm上の記載に基づくものであり、実際と異なる場合があります

Kubernetes

Kubernetes の場合は翻訳などコードに対する直接的な貢献でないものも多く含まれているため、kubernetes/kubernetes リポジトリと全体と言うカテゴリで分けて紹介します。Kubernetes は日本からの貢献者数が最も多く、93人という結果でした。

kubernetes/kubernetes リポジトリ

Kubernetes organization 全体

fluentd

fluentd では Contributionが 4 桁台の方が 3 名もいらっしゃいました。fluentd の世界全体としてもトップの数値となります。

Argo

Argo では 1 位の yu-croco さんが圧倒的でした。Contribution の数値はそこまで多くはないものの、日本からの貢献者数が 23 名と他の CNCF Graduated プロジェクトより多いと言うのが特徴的でした。

Containerd

Containerd では2023 年に CNCF Top Committer を受賞した、akihirosuda さんが圧倒的な数字となっていました。また、4392 と言う数字は全世界の貢献者の中でも1 位でした。

Cilium

2023 年に Graduated になったばかりの Cilium が 2024 年の日本からの貢献者が多いプロジェクトの 5 位となりました。これは日本からの注目度の高さ、勢いを感じる結果となりました。

CNCF 全体の Top 20

最後に CNCF 全体の Number の上位 20 名の日本人を紹介します。

終わりに

DevStats のデータを見ることで CNCF Project に貢献している開発者を数値で見ることができます。これらの人々の活動は CNCF 全体を日々支えています。このブログで彼らを紹介することがこれらの活動のモチベーションに少しでも繋がることになれば幸いです。また、この集計は 2024 年が最初となります。2025 年はどのようになるのか連続して観測することで意味のあるデータになることが期待されます。2025 年は KubeCon + CloudNativeCon Japan 2025 が開催されます。このカンファレンスを契機にさらに日本からの貢献が活発になることを祈ります。

また、今回のこのデータを見て、所属が古かったり、日本在住のはずだがランキングに載っていないという方もいると思います。これらの情報は cncf/gitdm から更新が可能です。
